questions.text: Which of the following factors maximally increases the risk of tubal pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Prior tubal surgery for ectopic pregnancy has the highest risk of tubal pregnancy among the given options.

Risk factors for ectopic pregnancy:

  • Prior ectopic pregnancy
  • Prior tubal surgery for ectopic, recanalization of tube post-sterilization
  • Pelvic inflammatory disease - most common cause for ectopic pregnancy
  • Infertility
  • Artificial reproductive therapy
  • Endometriosis
  • Smoking
  • Maternal age >40 years
  • Contraceptive methods - intrauterine device, progesterone-only pills

questions.text: Most common cause of acute diarrhoea in paediatric age group in India is :
questions.solution:
Rotavirus infection is the most common cause of diarrhoea in all children <5years of age.

Other agents are:

  • E.coli – second most common cause
  • Campylobacter jejuni
  • Salmonella
  • Shigella

questions.text: The most common benign tumor of bone is :
questions.solution:
Osteochondroma is the most common benign tumour of bone.

It is not a true neoplasm since its growth stops with cessation of growth at the epiphyseal plate. It is a result of an aberration at the growth plate, where a few cells from the plate grow centrifugally as a separate lump of bone.

Osteochondromas occur most commonly between 10–30 years of age.

Osteochondroma of tibia:

Osteoid Osteoma : It is the commonest true benign tumour of the bone. Pathologically, it consists of a nidus of tangled arrays of partially mineralised osteoid trabeculae surrounded by dense sclerotic bone.

questions.text: The most common primary Immunodeficiency is:
questions.solution:
The most common primary immunodeficiency is Isolated IgA immunodeficiency.

Selective IgA deficiency:-

  • Recurrent respiratory and genitourinary tract infections resulting from lack of secreted IgA on mucosal surfaces are common.
  • Problems such as intestinal malabsorption, allergic disease, and autoimmune disorders may also be associated with low IgA levels.

questions.text: What is the most common anomaly of the hepatic artery?

choices.text: Independent origin of the right and left hepatic arteries from the cealic axis
Replaced right hepatic artery arising from the superior mesentric artery

questions.solution:
The most common anomaly of the hepatic artery is replaced right hepatic artery arising from the superior mesenteric artery. 

Normally, the common hepatic artery gives off the right and left hepatic arteries. A middle hepatic artery branches off from the proximal left hepatic artery.

The replaced right hepatic artery directly supplies the right lobe of the liver.

Surgical significance: 

In individuals with replaced right hepatic artery, the diameter of the common hepatic artery is smaller. In liver transplant recipients, this can be a cause for the increased incidence of complications such as thrombosis.

Whereas, replaced right hepatic artery is a beneficial variant for donors undergoing donation of the right lobe of the liver. The replaced right hepatic artery provides a longer and larger graft thus reducing chances of thrombosis.

questions.text: The most common site for amebiasis is:-
questions.solution:
The most common site for amebiasis is cecum.

Amebiasis is caused by Entamoeba histolytica.

Although most cases of amebiasis are asymptomatic, dysentery and invasive extraintestinal disease can occur. Amebic liver abscess is the most common manifestation of invasive amebiasis.

  • E histolytica is transmitted via ingestion of the cystic form (infective stage) of the protozoa (fecal- oral route)
  • Excystation then occurs in the terminal ileum or colon, resulting in trophozoites (invasive form)
  • The trophozoites can penetrate and invade the colonic mucosal barrier, leading to tissue destruction, secretory bloody diarrhea, and colitis resembling inflammatory bowel disease.
  • In addition, the trophozoites can spread hematogenously via the portal circulation to the liver or even to more distant organs
  • E histolytica is capable of causing a spectrum of illnesses. Intestinal conditions resulting from E histolytica infection include the following:
    • Asymptomatic infection
    • Symptomatic noninvasive infection
    • Acute proctocolitis (dysentery)
    • Fulminant colitis with perforation
    • Toxic megacolon
    • Chronic nondysenteric colitis
    • Ameboma
    • Perianal ulceration

Extraintestinal conditions resulting from E histolytica infection include the following:

  • Liver abscess
  • Pleuropulmonary disease
  • Peritonitis
  • Pericarditis
  • Brain abscess
  • Genitourinary disease

questions.text: A patient has enlarged neck veins, hepatomegaly and a holosystolic murmur along the lower left sternal margin. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in the above clinical scenario is tricuspid regurgitation.

Clinical features of tricuspid regurgitation are:

  • Distended neck veins with prominent c-v waves
  • Hepatomegaly with systolic pulsations
  • Positive hepatojugular reflex - the distension of the jugular vein when firm pressure is applied over the liver
  • Blowing holosystolic murmur along the lower left sternal margin

questions.text: A 55-year-old female patient who is a known case of hypertension, diabetes, and hyperlipidemia presents to the emergency department with a severe headache and vomiting. The patient is agitated and her blood pressure is 220/120 mmHg. Ophthalmoscopy reveals the presence of papilledema. Which of the following antihypertensive is least useful in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The above scenario points towards the diagnosis of malignant hypertension. The drug which is least useful in the management is furosemide(diuretic). 

Volume depletion is common in patients with malignant hypertension, and the administration of a diuretic together with a hypertensive agent can lead to an extreme drop in blood pressure.

Diuretics are generally not recommended for the rapid reduction of blood pressure in patients with hypertensive crises. They are used only in conditions of volume overload such as acute pulmonary edema.

Related Pearl: Parenteral drugs used in hypertensive emergencies

 

Drugs

Contraindications

Beta-blockers

 Labetalol, esmolol, metoprolol

Heart block, systolic heart failure, asthma bradycardia

Calcium channel blockers

Clevidipine, nicardipine

Advanced aortic stenosis 

D1 receptor agonist

 Fenoldopam

Caution in glaucoma

Vasodilators

 

 

Nitroglycerin

 Pericardial tamponade

Nitroprusside

 Relatively contraindicated in liver failure and renal failure 

Hydralazine

  CAD, RHD

ACE inhibitors

Enalaprilat

 History of angioedema

Alpha-blocker

Phentolamine, Urapidil

  Aortic stenosis, AV shunt

Centrally acting sympatholytics

Clonidine

 Severe AV block, sick-sinus syndrome

questions.text: The most important stimulus controlling the level of resting ventilation is_____

choices.text: pH of CSF on central chemoreceptors

questions.solution:
The most important stimulus comes from the pH of the CSF on the central chemoreceptors. The CO2 that enters the brain and CSF is hydrated to H2CO3 and dissociates, leading to rising H+ levels. The CSF H+ concentration hence parallels the arterial CO2 levels.

The effect of pO2 on peripheral chemoreceptors under normoxic conditions is very small. Changes in pCO2 do affect the peripheral chemoreceptors, but the magnitude is less than that for the central chemoreceptors.

The effect of changes in the pH on peripheral chemoreceptors under normal conditions is small: and the changes in pO2 do not affect the central chemoreceptors.

questions.text:
Which of the following lipoproteins have the highest cholesterol:triglyceride ratio?

VLDL- Very low-density lipoprotein

LDL- Low-density lipoprotein 

HDL- High-density lipoprotein 

IDL- Intermediate-density lipoprotein
questions.solution:
As cholesterol is the predominant lipid in LDL and HDL, they have a higher cholesterol: triglyceride ratio.

VLDL also has a significant amount of cholesterol but it predominantly comprises triglycerides (lower cholesterol: triglyceride ratio). Therefore LDL and HDL are considered the major carriers of cholesterol.

IDLs are formed by the removal of triglycerides from VLDL by muscle and adipose tissue and are hence enriched in cholesterol. LDLs are derived from VLDL and IDL particles and contain more cholesterol than IDLs.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old man presents with a history of fatigue, dark-coloured urine and photosensitivity. He consumes alcohol regularly. On examination, hyperpigmentation and scarring are present on the face and dorsum of the hand. Lab findings are given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Hb: 7.4 mg/dl
Peripheral blood picture: Suggestive of microcytic hypochromic anaemia
Urinary porphobilinogen level: Normal
Urinary uroporphyrin level: Increased
questions.solution:
A middle-aged adult presenting with features of hemolysis and photosensitivity with elevated urine uroporphyrin suggests a diagnosis of porphyria cutanea tarda.

Porphyria cutanea tarda (PCT) is the most common porphyria. It is caused by the deficiency of uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase, which converts uroporphyrinogen III to coproporphyrinogen III.  It is characterized by photosensivity, which manifests as blistering skin lesions on the back of the hands with crusting and scarring. It is associated with hemochromatosis and patients may develop chronic liver disease. There is increased excretion of uroporphyrin in the urine.

Related Pearl: Types of porphyria

Clinically porphyrias can be classified into:

  • Hepatic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in the liver.
  • Erythropoietic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in bone marrow erythroid cells.
Porphyria type
Deficient  enzyme
Lab findings
  
Symptoms
X-linked dominant protoporphyria
(XLDPP)
δ-aminolevulinate synthase 2
(ALAS - 2)
 Decreased RBC count and hemoglobin
Cutaneous photosensitivity
Photosensitivity
Aminolevulinate dehydratase deficiency porphyria
(ALADP)
δ-aminolevulinate dehydratase
(ALAD)
 Increased urinary ALA and coproporphyrin III  Neurovisceral symptoms
Abdominal pain, neuropathy
Acute intermittent porphyria
(AIP)
Hydroxymethylbilane synthase
(Uroporphyrin I synthase)
 Increased urinary ALA and PBG  Neurovisceral symptoms 
Periodic abdominal pain, peripheral neuropathy, psychiatric symptoms, tachycardia
Congenital Erythropoietic porphyria
(CEP)
Uroporphyrinogen III synthase
(UROS)
 Increased urinary, fecal and red cell uroporphyrin I Cutaneous photosensitivity
Severe photosensitivity with erythema, swelling and blistering, hemolytic anemia, splenomegaly
Porphyria cutanea tarda (PCT)
Uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase
(UROD)
 Increased uroporphyrin I  
Cutaneous photosensitivity
Photosensitivity with vesicles and bullae
Hereditary coproporphyria
(HCP)
Coproporphyrinogen oxidase
(CPOX)
 Increased urinary ALA, PBG, and coproporphyrin III and fecal coproporphyrin III Both
Photosensitivity, neurologic symptoms, abdominal colic
Variegate porphyria
(VP)
Protoporphyrinogen oxidase
(PPOX)
 Increased urinary ALA, PBG, and coproporphyrin III and fecal protoporphyrin IX Both
Photosensitivity, neurologic symptoms, developmental delay
Erythropoietic protoporphyria
(EPP)
Ferrochelatase
(FECH)
 Increased fecal and red cell protoporphyrin IX  Cutaneous photosensitivity
Non-blistering Photosensitivity with skin lesions
 
Most porphyrias are autosomal dominant except:
  • ALAD enzyme deficiency porphyria
  • Congenital erythropoietic porphyria
  • Erythropoietic protoporphyria
  • X-linked protoporphyria

questions.text: What is the most common reaction occurring in patients undergoing blood transfusions?
questions.solution:
The most common blood transfusion reaction is the febrile nonhemolytic reaction.

Related Pearl: Blood Transfusion Reactions

Immunological Transfusion Reactions             

Reaction
(Onset)

 Mechanism Presentation Management

Anaphylactic transfusion reaction

(Seconds-minutes)

Common in IgA deficient recipients 

Shock, respiratory distress, angioedema

Stop transfusion immediately, give epinephrine

Prevention – using IgA deficient plasma and washed cellular blood components

Allergic/ Urticarial transfusion reaction

(Within 2-3 hours)

Recipient IgE against donor components causing mast cell activation

Urticaria, flushing, pruritus

Stop transfusion immediately, aggressively manage with IV fluids

Febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction

(within 6h)

 

(Most common complication of blood transfusion)

Antibodies against donor WBC and HLA antigens (sensitization)

Cytokine accumulation during blood storage

More common in multipally transfused patients and multiparous women

Fever and chills sometimes with mild dyspnoea

Antihistamines and antipyretics

Transfusion can be stopped if symptoms are severe

Prevention: Leukoreduced products

Transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI)

(1-6 hours)

Anti-HLA type 2 antibodies in donor plasma bind recipient WBCs, increase capillary permeability

Hypoxia, non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema

CXR: Bilateral interstitial infiltrates

Stop transfusion immediately

Supportive care

Acute hemolytic transfusion reaction

(during transfusion to within 24h)

ABO incompatibility

(Type 2 hypersensitivity)

Pre-existing high affinity IgM antibodies rapidly induce complement mediated lysis, intra-vascular hemolysis, and hemoglobinuria

Fever, chills, flank/back pain

Sense of impending doom

Hemoglobinuria

DIC, Renal failure

Coomb’s test positive, pink plasma

Stop transfusion immediately, aggressively manage with IV fluids

Delayed hemolytic transfusion reaction

occurs after 24 hours ( usually 2 weeks )

Recipients have prior exposure to RBC antigens. After the transfusion, anamnestic response results in antibody production

Typically caused by IgG antibodies to foreign protein antigens and are associated with laboratory features of hemolysis.

Mild fever, hemolytic anemia

Coomb’s test positive

Screening for new antibodies positive

Supportive care

Additional transfusions if needed

Non-immune mediated transfusion reactions are as follows:

  • Transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO)
  • Hypothermia
  • Electrolyte abnormality- hyperkalemia, hypocalcemia
  • Iron overload
  • Transient hypotension
  • Immunomodulation
  • Blood-borne infections

questions.text: Most common route of nosocomial infections:
questions.solution:
• Most common route of nosocomial infections are through direct contact.
  • Indirect contact refers to contact with infectious objects.
  • Vehicle transmission and droplet transmission are also routes of nosocomial infections.
  • Nosocomial infections are hospital acquired infections like blood stream infections and surgical site infections.

questions.text: The most common banding technique used for the staining of chromosomes in Karyotyping is
questions.solution:
• G banding (Giemsa banding) is the most common technique used in cytogenetics to produce a visible karyotype by staining condensed chromosomes.
  • It is useful for identifying genetic diseases through the photographic representation of the entire chromosome complement.
  • The metaphase chromosomes are treated with trypsin (to partially digest the chromosome) and stained with Giemsa stain.
  • Heterochromatic regions, which tend to be rich with adenine and thymine (AT-rich) DNA and relatively gene-poor, stain more darkly and appear as Dark bands in G-banding.
  • In contrast, less condensed chromatin—which tends to be rich with guanine and cytosine (GC-rich) and more transcriptionally active—incorporates less Giemsa stain, and these regions appear as light bands in G-banding.

questions.text: Which of the following types is the most common presentation of psoriatic arthritis?
questions.solution:
Asymmetric oligoarthritis is the most common type of Psoriatic arthritis.

Asymmetric oligoarthritis commonly involves a knee or another large joint with a few small joints in the fingers or toes, often with dactylitis.

Psoriatic arthritis is a seronegative inflammatory arthritis that is destructive to the joints, associated with moderate to severe psoriasis. It usually develops before 40 years of age.

A diagnosis of psoriatic arthritis can be made from the Classification Criteria for Psoriatic Arthritis (CASPAR) criteria, if there is an inflammatory articular disease of a joint, enthesis or spine, along with >=3 of the following criteria:

  1. Current or history of psoriasis/ family history of psoriasis
  2. Typical psoriatic nail involvement
  3. Rheumatoid factor negative
  4. Current or history of dactylitis
  5. Radiological evidence of juxta-articular new bone formation

Triggers include trauma to a joint or tendon (Koebner effect), smoking, alcohol excess and HIV infection. Streptococcal infection, medications like lithium or stress do not trigger the onset of psoriatic arthritis. There is an activation of both innate and acquired immunity with the overproduction of cytokines like TNF‐α, IL‐17 and IL‐23 via the JAK-STAT pathway. This results in joint fibrosis and erosion of bone with abnormal bone formation.

Wright & Moll Classification of Psoriatic Arthritis

  • Arthritis of the DIP joints
  • Asymmetric oligoarthritis
  • Symmetric polyarthritis
  • Axial involvement such as spine and sacroiliac joints
  • Arthritis mutilans, a destructive form of arthritis

Psoriatic arthritis involves proximal and distal interphalangeal joints (PIP, DIP) and metacarpophalangeal joints (MCP). Clinical features include:

  • Early morning stiffness
  • Swollen, tender, one or more joints
  • Enthesitis: Heel pain due to Achilles tendon inflammation
  • Plantar fasciitis
  • Dactylitis /sausage fingers with telescoping (shortening of toes due to osteolysis)
  • Nail changes: hyperkeratosis and onycholysis
  • Axial involvement may occur

The image below shows psoriatic arthritis of the hands:

 

Investigations include:

  • Inflammatory markers like CRP, ESR
  • Tests to rule out other arthritis: uric acid, rheumatoid factor, anti-CCP antibodies
  • Plain X‐rays of the hands and feet in erosive disease, which show:
    • Pencil-in-cup deformity of distal interphalangeal joint
    • Marginal erosions with adjacent bony proliferation 'whiskering'
  • MRI to assess axial disease and enthesitis

Given below is an X-ray showing the 'pencil-in-cup' appearance of the metacarpophalangeal joints

Psoriatic arthritis should be managed by a rheumatologist. Early treatment and interventions are necessary to prevent irreversible joint damage. The Group for Research and Assessment of Psoriasis and Psoriatic Arthritis (GRAPPA) management guidelines for psoriatic arthritis states the use of the following drugs in:

  • Peripheral arthritis: NSAIDs/ steroid injection/ Systemic treatments - methotrexate, cyclosporin/ biologicals
  • Dactylitis: NSAIDs/ Steroid injection
  • Axial disease / Enthesitis: NSAIDs / Physiotherapy / Biologicals

Tofacitinib is a novel, oral JAK 1/3 - Inhibitor which will inhibit the JAK-STAT pathway responsible for the production of cytokines and chemokines. It has been approved for the treatment of psoriatic arthritis, and is also used in rheumatoid arthritis and ulcerative colitis.

Newer drugs approved for the treatment of Psoriatic arthritis include:

Class of drug Drugs
Anti-TNF α

- Infliximab (only iv drug, rest all are s/c)
- Etanercept 
- Adalimumab 
- Golimumab
- Certolizumab
Anti-IL-17 - Secukinumab 
Anti-IL-23 - Ustekinumab 

Psoriatic arthritis is found to be associated with ocular diseases like conjunctivitis, uveitis, iridocyclitis, keratoconjunctivitis sicca and cataracts, obesity/metabolic syndrome, alcohol misuse and premature cardiovascular disease.

Differential diagnoses include:

  • Early rheumatoid arthritis
  • Ankylosing spondylitis
  • Gout
  • Osteoarthritis
  • Fibromyalgia

Asymmetric oligoarthritis is the most common type of psoriatic arthritis. Previously, symmetric polyarthritis was marked as the correct answer (based on Harrison's Textbook of Internal Medicine 20th Edition). However, after thorough review of literature and consultation of expert faculty, the answer has been changed to asymetric oligoarthritis as per:

  • Rook′s Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition - (Page no 35.44) 
  • ABC of Rheumatology 2018, Wiley-Blackwell- British Medical Journal (Page No 85)
  • Kelley and Firestein's Textbook of Rheumatology, 10th Edition (Page No 1288)

questions.text: The  most common causative organism of pyomyositis is:
questions.solution:
Staphylococcus aureus is the most common organism causing Pyomyositis.

Pyomyositis also known as tropical pyomyositis or myositis tropicans is a bacterial infection of skeletal muscles resulting in pus filled abscess that is seen primarily in tropical climates but also occurs in immunocompromised and HIV-infected patients.

Causative Organism:

  • Tropical pyomyositis – Most Common cause is S. Aureus
  • Acute bacterial myositis – Most Common cause is Group A Streptococcus
  • Overall - Most Common cause of pyomyositis is S.aureus

Clinical Presentation:

  • Children aged 2 – 5 years are most commonly affected.
  • Pyomyositis presents as fever, swelling, and pain overlying the involved muscle.
  • Most common Muscles infected by pyomyositis are Quadriceps and Gluteal Muscles.

Treatment:

  • Surgical drainage of abscess followed by antibiotics for minimum three weeks to treat infection.

questions.text: Most common cause of failure of male sterilization is:

choices.text: Advanced age at the time of procedure

questions.solution:
Most common cause of failure of male sterilization or vasectomy is mistake in identifying the vas.

Although the failure rate of vasectomy is low, sometimes failure arises as some other structure in the spermatic cord is taken.

Histological confirmation or microscopy with staining is recommended in vasectomy procedures.

questions.text: Which among the following is the best device to detect abnormal hemoglobins?
questions.solution:
CO-oximeter is the best device to detect abnormal hemoglobins.

CO-oximeter utilizes an eight wavelength sensor (unlike pulse oximeter which uses two wavelengths) to distinguish between oxygenated blood, deoxygenated blood and blood containing CO. 

CO-oximeter is useful in measuring:

  • Carboxyhemoglobin
  • Methemoglobin

questions.text: The drug cevimeline acts on which receptor for the expulsion of the secretions from the salivary gland?
questions.solution:
Cevimeline is a muscarinic agonist with affinity for both M1 and M3 receptors on the lacrimal and salivary glands.

While M1 activation results in increased secretion, M3 activation results in smooth muscle contraction and expulsion of the secretions.

Cevimeline has a long-lasting sialogogic action and may have fewer side effects than pilocarpine.

Cevimeline enhances lacrimal secretions in Sjögren’s syndrome. The usual dose is 30 mg three times daily.

questions.text: Which of the following is an important epidemiological tool to assess disability in children?

choices.text: Wing’s Comprehensive Handicaps, Behaviour and Skills Schedule

questions.solution:
Wing’s Comprehensive Handicaps, Behaviour and Skills Schedule (HBS) has been used in epidemiological studies to assess the total child population in terms of detailed scales of specific abilities and disabilities.

HBS is not useful for children with mental retardation.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common form of acute transient psychotic disorder?

choices.text: Acute polymorphic psychotic disorder without symptoms of schizophrenia
Acute polymorphic psychotic disorder with symptoms of schizophrenia

questions.solution:
The most common form of acute transient psychotic disorders is polymorphic psychotic disorder without symptoms of schizophrenia (one third to a half of all cases).

This is followed by polymorphic psychotic disorder with symptoms of schizophrenia.

Polymorphic psychotic disorder commonly presents with marked hallucinations, delusions, and perceptual disturbances that change in type and intensity from day to day or even from hour to hour.

questions.text: What is the earliest sign of left atrial enlargement on a chest x-ray ?

choices.text: Elevation of left main bronchus and widening of carina

questions.solution:
Enlargement of the left atrial appendage is the earliest sign of left atrial enlargement (LAE) on a chest x-ray.  It is seen as a fullness below the pulmonary artery. 

Other radiographic signs seen in LAE include:

  • The third mogul sign represents an enlargement of the left atrial appendage along the upper left cardiac border, leading to straightening of the left heart border.
  • Posterior displacement of the oesophagus - seen on the lateral view of the barium swallow study.
  • Elevation of left main bronchus and widening of the carina.
  • Double density sign or double atrial shadow - the enlarged LA extends towards the right cardiac border, hence, both RA and LA borders can be seen distinctly over the right heart border (as shown below):

The X-ray below demonstrates straightening of the left cardiac border and widening of the carina, with the carinal angle becoming more obtuse, reflecting left atrial enlargement.

 The causes of left atrial enlargement are as follows:

  • Congenital: Ventricular septal defect , Patent ductus arteriosus
  • Acquired: Mitral valvular disease, left ventricular failure, left atrial myxoma

questions.text: Most common mode of occupational lead poisoning is:
questions.solution:
• Inhalation of fumes and dust of lead is the most common mode of occupational lead poisoning.
  • Ingestion and absorption through skin are other modes of occupational lead poisoning in industries.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most accepted theory for secondary cholesteatoma?
questions.solution:
The most accepted theory for secondary cholesteatoma is Habermann's theory. It proposes that the skin of the external auditory meatus grows or migrates into the middle ear through the posterosuperior marginal perforation or attic perforation forming cholesteatoma.

Related Pearl: Classification and theories for origin of cholesteatoma

Classification:

Congenital cholesteatoma is that which has its nidus of trapped squamous epithelium present at birth.

Primary acquired cholesteatoma is associated with a defect in the pars flaccida. 

Secondary acquired cholesteatoma is associated with a defect in the pars tensa.

Tertiary acquired cholesteatoma is defined as that which occurs behind a normal-appearing tympanic membrane as the result of implantation of an antecedent middle ear inflammation.

 
Type
Theory
Description
Congenital Cholesteatoma
Congenital cell rests
The presence of congenital epithelial cell rests within the middle ear cleft/ temporal bone.
Primary Acquired Cholesteatoma
Wittmaack’s theory of retraction pockets
Negative middle ear pressure leads to the formation of retraction pockets (usually in the posterosuperior part of pars tensa and the pars flaccida) which accumulates keratin debris.
Ruedi’s theory of basal cell hyperplasia
The basal cell layer of the germinal layer of skin proliferates in response to infection & other stimuli.
Sade’s Metaplasia theory
Repeated infections (Otitis media with effusion) lead to metaplasia of middle ear epithelium into squamous type.
Secondary Acquired Cholesteatoma
Habermann’s theory of epithelial invasion
Marginal perforation leads to ingrowth of squamous epithelium of the meatus or outer surface of the tympanic membrane into middle ear.
Sade’s Metaplasia theory
Repeated infections (ASOM/CSOM) lead to metaplasia of middle ear epithelium into squamous type.

ASOM: Acute suppurative otitis media; CSOM: Chronic suppurative otitis media.

questions.text: A 45-year-old Nigerian man hailing from an area endemic for river blindness presented with the given finding. What is the drug of choice for the treatment?
questions.solution:
The image shows sclerosing keratitis of onchocerciasis or river blindness. The drug of choice for the treatment of onchocerciasis is ivermectin. 

Ivermectin: 6 mg, single-dose, repeated every 6-12 months, according to the weight of the patient. 

Suramin and diethylcarbamazine (DEC) were given in the past but have been discontinued due to serious adverse effects.
